summary: The Format May Be Dead, But That Means Savings For Me.
reviewText: I bought one of these HD DVD drives for the Xbox 360 when they were first released, and while I liked the quality of HD DVD, the ease of connection, and the general features of this device, I also couldn't justify the price of it or HD DVD movies at the time. DVD was cheaper, and when upscaled by the Xbox 360, looked almost as good as HD DVD in some cases. My Xbox 360 was itself incredibly noisy, and I also didn't love that I needed to connect via VGA in order to get that upscaling or the high-quality image that HD DVD provides... So I returned the HD DVD player and waited for a format to emerge the winner.Fast-forward to late 2009. I've got a new Jasper model Xbox 360 which runs quietly and has a HDMI port. I decided to get the HD DVD player for two reasons:1. The HD DVD player for Xbox 360 is the cheapest HD media player available.2. There are more than 800 HD DVD titles out there that work with this player, and they're all available at bargain prices.For WAY less than the cost of a Blu-Ray player alone, I got an HD DVD player and several movies. I realize the format is dead, but HD DVD doesn't have region codes, and so I'm free to choose from any of the 800+ HD DVD titles that were released around the world. Imports work fine on thi player, and most of them offer English in some way. Import titles include many movies that were not released on HD DVD in America, and I'm able to find titles for under $5 these days. No, I won't get anything new on HD DVD. Production stopped in 2008, and so I won't be able to get the last three Harry Potter movies on HD DVD, for example. However, the first several ARE on HD DVD, as are great movies like Blade Runner, Dawn of the Dead, and several others that I enjoy watching many times over the years.Of course, being a dead format, I can't expect much support from Microsoft for this device, but I figure that used and left-over HD DVD players will be laying around in pawn shops and online stores collecting dust for the next decade or so, and so I'm not too worried about being saddled with movies I can't watch. There will always be some cheap alternative to get back into watching HD DVDs.And as a bonus, this player lets me watch DVDs on my Xbox 360 without putting the wear & tear on my console's primary optical drive. That's a handy thing.Negatives include the drive's need for an additional AC outlet, and of course, the fact that the format is dead.This is obviously not the best choice for everyone at this late stage, and I'm sure I'll grab a standalone Blu-Ray player some day soon (I had a PS3, but Blu-ray Discs were still too expensive to be worth it to me), but for now it's a low-cost way to get the most out of my HDTV. It's a lesser substitute for the winner of the format war, but it will do for now.As an aside, I will say that I prefer HD DVD as a format over Blu-ray Disc. HD DVD has better menu features, no region codes, smoother controls, and better network features. Blu-ray, while looking just as good as HD DVD, has gone through several specs just to get to the point of being CLOSE to HD DVD in terms of bonus features. I really wish that the major studios would have fought harder to make HD DVD the winner, but alas! It was not to be. HD DVD has joined Super 8, Betamax, Laserdisc, and VideoDisc in the hall of dead video media formats. Now all that remains is to see what kind of afterlife it can maintain.

description: A sci-fi/action RPG from acclaimed developer Gearbox,Borderlandscombines the best in first-person action gaming with elements of a traditional role-playing game (RPG). The excitement of this hybridization is further magnified by the game's groundbreaking content generation system which allows for a near-endless variety in missions, environments, enemies, weapons, item drops and character customization, making the game's single player, multiplayer and online campaigns not to be missed..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; }FPS/RPG hybrid gameplay.View larger.Literally thousands of weapons.View larger.Vehicular combat.View larger.StoryIn a distant future, the planets at the outer edges of the galaxy have become a beacon to fortune seekers and those yearning for a better life off world. But there are no guarantees in deep space. Pandora, one of these distant planets, was reported to be rich in untapped mineral wealth, and so drew many hoping to get rich quick, but in the end little was found beyond the scattered ruins of a past alien civilization. With nothing to gain, any who could soon abandoned Pandora, leaving those who remained to deal with the lawlessness of a world gone bust, and the mystery of the long-dead alien civilization. But as chaotic as these times were, there were worse days yet to come. After several years the planet's huge orbit slowly brought it near to its sun and once unknown and horrifying creatures sprang from their long hibernation to terrify the stranded colonists. The only hope of the colonists seems to be a vault discovered in the side of a mountainside, rumored to contain alien technology and secrets about Pandora. Will this discovery be the colonist's salvation or their end? Discover their fate inBorderlands.GameplayAs in a traditional RPG,Borderlandsis built around the continual leveling of characters as they delve into quests. These quests include both story-driven adventures and side quests that offer players rewards such as items exclusive to quest completion and/or forward movement of the story. Players can look forward to action set in both single player and multiplayer modes--including co-op play--as well as vehicular combat, literally thousands of different types of weapons that change each time you play and randomly generated maps and map features.Playable CharactersBorderlandsfeatures several playable characters, each with its own unique backstory, abilities and skills. Skills can be leveled up, allowing for improvement of things like health, accuracy with weapons and capacity for items. In addition to this, characters possess unique skill tree development, ensuring that each will develop differently regardless of time spend leveling them up.Key Game FeaturesCo-op Design-Borderlandsis built from the ground up to be an exciting, intuitive cooperative experience for up to four players simultaneously that rewards players who work together and invest in co-op skills. Split screen is also supported.FPS Gameplay- In this role-playing shooter, choose one of four distinct characters, each with their own individual skill sets. As your character grows throughout this fast-paced FPS, you choose and customize your abilities to suit your style of play.Art Style- The game's distinctive art style combines traditional rendering techniques with hand-drawn textures to paint a bold and eye-catching spin on the FPS genre.Vehicular Combat- Jump behind the wheel and engage in high-speed vehicle-to-vehicle combat, complete with spectacular explosions and road-killed Skags.Frontier Planet- Search the wasteland planet of Pandora for the legendary alien vault. Fight your way through bandits, discover nine native (and aggressive) creatures, and help the few settlers on the planet in your search for a Vault rumored to contain a great prize - if it even exists.Gun Lust- Choose from literally hundreds of thousands of weapons, each with their own manufacturers, specifications, and advantages. The revolutionary content generation system guarantees that you'll find almost infinite tools of destruction to suit your play style.Online Multiplayer Support-Borderlandssupports 2-4 players via PlayStation Network.

reviewText: Pretty much what everyone else said.  Since they went and gave you all the positives I'll focus on the negatives.  This is not a negative review but flaws I found to be annoying in an outstanding game and possibly the best sports game ever made.I've had the game since launch and haven't even gone to the Jordan Challenge yet because I've been stuck on Association mode.  Trading is realistic in that you can't entice a team with scrubs and some draft picks for Dwayne Wade.  They will aggressively pursue your good players in a chance to get something back in return.  If I want LeBron (I would never but hypothetically) then I will have to trade Dwight Howard and a first rounder at least.  I also love the idea of draft day trades.  However, computer generated rookies often come in rated way too high.  1st pick coming in at an 84 is unrealistic.  Danny Granger starts off at like an 83.The player development is still iffy at best and I still do not like the development points and only being able to develop a player once a month.  It just seems dumb to me.  Also there are not enough drills for the attributes.  There's a shooting drill but it will not improve 3 pt shooting or Free Throws, developing a back to the basket game is completely useless because 9 times out of 10 the player is not good enough to make the necessary amount of shots to even upgrade.  The dribbling drill has always been dumb, with that weave through cones nonsense.  Strength, shoot in traffic, ball security, passing (a whole nother paragraph) and many more attributes cannot be upgraded via drills.  It's just dumb.  This results in manually editing players and you know how that goes with 99% of people lol Dwight Howard will turn into Hakeem Olajuwon on offense.Well I still don't like the player attitudes.  Way too often everyone thinks they should start.  If I have Joe Johnson at Shooting Guard, no other shooting guard will start over him unless their name is Wade or Kobe.  Far too often, these rookies, bench players, bout to retires, and journeymen will grumble about playing time where there is no way to check them unless it's through more playing time or a trade.  We need the reality check option and should be based on the coach's rating and accomplishments.  Players with a 73 rating thinking they should be starting over my 90 SG get out of here.  This also hurts when trying to build a solid bench.  It wouldn't be so much of a problem except it messes up team chemistry and lowers the rating of the player.  The coaches don't progress.  So if the team makes the playoffs 5 years in a row your coach will still be a D, assistant coaches still cannot be promoted to head coach, and coaches 10 years in the league retire for no reason.Also the season tasks are limited once again.  Win the division, make the playoffs, etc. are nice milestones but what about a team leading the league in scoring or in defense?  What about a player leading the league in rebounding?  Win the regular season series against your rivals, Win one playoff series, Win two playoff series? Hold Kevin Durant under 25 pts...etc. etc.  These things could add more development points at the end of the season for development of players but now as it's structured only the good teams and their players get better.  What about Kevin Love?  Can he get some development points playing for the worst team in the league?  Probably not.  And once again at the end of the season I should be able to send Josh Smith to shooting camp and rebounding camp or as many camps as I please.There's a few aspects of gameplay that I want to address as well.  The first is the very awful passing system.  I understand that players must make smart passes and all that good stuff.  However, I saw more deflected passes in 5 games of NBA 2K11 than I have in an entire season of watching NBA on TV.  It borders to the point of ridiculousness.  If an NBA player can't pass from the wing to the post, or from the high post to the wing, or from middle of the court 3 pt line to the wing then they have no use in the NBA.Passes on fast breaks are too often stolen while the computer completes the same court length pass on their break.  The simplest passes get stolen or tipped and most of the time it's horse booboo.  But the computer is throwing alley oops with Dwight Howard standing right in the paint.  The same pass that gets stolen 98% of the time for you the computer makes that same dumb pass and converts it. The game also has the weird habit of bypassing a player.  For example I have Dwight on the block.  Instead of passing it to Dwight you will send a cross court pass across the lane and several defenders that will end up getting stolen.  I should not have to icon pass to player standing right next to me.The fast breaks are pretty bad as well and it's something they haven't gotten quite right since...well...ever.  Players frequently (and I do mean frequently) get caught from behind on a fast break.  Two on ones are impossible because of the horrible mechanic of passing and the unrealistic percentage of tipped passes.  A two on one will probably be stolen by the sole point guard back to defend the fast break or he will body my 220 lb SF running full speed.  Also players leading the fast break still run to the 3 point line for no apparent reason when only the trailers should be running to the three point line.  The defensive fast break is even worse because even though you've gotten back to prevent the fast break the computer still completes the pass through 3 of my defenders en route to a layup or dunk.  A lot of times the first one back will run away from the basket for no reason allowing a computer player to get a layup...it's just crazy.  They will be standing there defending the basket and then just move for no reason as soon as the opposition comes.The last gripe is that players change directions slowly when you have them but are as fluid as ever with the computer controlling them.  I can't even halfway show a double team without the ball being kicked out to a wide open player and my player unable to change directions like he's stuck in the mud.  These are pro athletes they can change directions quickly.  I could see if it was like Dirk Nowitzki or somebody but a standard NBA guard should be able to show a double team and get back at least in an athletic motion.  Also after a pump fake and the defender is in the air it's nearly impossible to just run right by them without them making an unrealistic recovery.  It's to the point of ridiculousness.  The defender jumps and before you can even take a dribble he's back on the ground and recovered.Another thing, Andre Miller is not unstoppable. description: GoldenEye 007has been a huge success for Rareware, and it's easy to see why. More than a simple movie translation, this has earned its top-seller status on its own. Fans ofDoomandQuakewill recognize the first-person shooter perspective, but there the similarity ends. James Bond 007 has too much style to simply blast everything in sight and move to the next level. No, as 007, the player has a variety of different missions to perform, each with its own specific objectives. Each mission follows thefilmclosely, and so James must use stealth and cunning as much as brute force. But if you see a Kalashnikov rifle lying around, by all means pick it up.Controls are easy to master, which is impressive considering the variety of actions the onscreen hero can perform. James can run and walk at variable speeds, duck, pivot, hide, attach mines to enemy helicopters, block doors from opening, and more. The optional auto-aim feature is especially nice. Of course, James Bond is proficient in a wide variety of weapons. You get to use them all, from the trusty Walther PPK (with silencer) to double sets of full-auto machine guns.The game's faithful tribute to the Bond legacy includes briefing dossiers on each mission, complete with wisecracks from Q and flirtatious comments from Moneypenny. And the 3-D representation of locations and characters from the movie is very impressive. The Rareware team spent time on the set with digital cameras, and it shows.One of the distinguishing features of the game is the outstanding artificial intelligence of the enemies. When attacked, squads will rush to hit the alarm. If they make it, reinforcements come running. Enemy soldiers respond to being shot or blown up with chilling realism. According to Rareware, there are over 30 different animation routines that come into play, depending on where the soldier is hit. For those who prefer the challenge of human opponents, there are six clever multiplayer modes where up to four players can shoot it out, as teams or solo agents.With excellent gameplay, intelligence, and style,GoldenEye 007is a first-person shooter that'll keep you coming back for more.--Jeanne UyPros:Built-in save capability for up to 4 playersAuto-aim feature helps novice players feel like a sharpshooterRich, complex game world filled with detail and varietyGreat bonus missionsCons:Sometimes cinematic scenes for fulfilling mission objectives are a bit anticlimactic

description: Tomb Raider: Anniversary retraces Lara Croft's original genre-defining adventure, as she pursues the legendary Scion artifact. New graphics, technology and physics bring Lara's adventure up-to-date and offers gamers a completely new game play experience. Re-imagined, Anniversary delivers a dynamic fluidly and fast Lara Croft, massive environments of stunning visuals, intense combat and game pacing, and an enhanced and clarified original story. Enter into strange, undiscovered lands and solve their deepest, darkest mysteries, open doors to new realms, uncover great rewards and unearth secrets to Lara's past.
reviewText: 1996 marked the arrival of the first, and highly influential, Tomb Raider, which introduced gamers to the Indiana Jones-esque heroine Lara Croft and marked one of the finest examples of true 3-D gameplay at the time.  After a number of years, as well as a number of unremarkable sequels that really downplayed what the series was about in the first place, Crystal Dynamics and Eidos marked a return to form with last year's Tomb Raider: Legend, which brought the core gameplay back to it's roots.  Now, to celebrate the release of the original Tomb Raider over a decade later, we get Tomb Raider: Anniversary, and be glad for it.  A re-imagining of the original game using the Tomb Raider: Legend graphics engine, Anniversary finds Lara in her usual environment: various tombs scattered in exotic locales.  While locating artifacts and gunning down baddies, you solve puzzles to progress through the game while engaging in some inventive platforming and acrobatics; all of which leads up to quite an explosive finale.  There are plenty of new elements to go along with the classic gameplay, including a new adrenaline dodge and challenging, multi-layered puzzles.  The graphics and textures look pretty good for a late in life PS2 game, and yes, Lara herself looks great as well, but there are a few noticable hiccups, especially noticed if played in Progressive Scan mode.  That aside, the rest of Tomb Raider: Anniversary is a smashing homage/remake of the classic first installment that is surprisingly pretty flawless in it's delivery.  Whether you are a casual or hardcore fan of the franchise, you should definitely consider picking up Tomb Raider: Anniversary.

description: Resident Evil 4 Wii
reviewText: I've never been much of a gamer but my son had Resident Evil 4 and had always talked about what a great game it is.  I'm over 40 and never expected to like it at all but I did decide to sit down and give it a try.  I finally pried my stiff fingers from the remote several hours later.  Since then, I run back to the Wii set up and play every chance I get.  I'm definitely still a beginner and it has taken me forever to get to level 4 but I'm learning fast.  The graphics are great and really make you feel a part of the action.  Yes, it is definitely gorey and violent.  It is not for children under 17.  If, however, you're an adult who enjoys horror movies then I think you'd enjoy this game as well.  I've always loved zombie films since seeing Night of the Living Dead when I was a youngster and this is like playing a role in a zombie movie.  Be warned, however, that this game is highly habit forming and may lead to serious neglect of your laundry and other household chores.  It's definitely a guilty pleasure for me.  I'm embarassed to tell my other adult female friends that I'm addicted to RE 4 but I am and I can't help myself!

description: Taking up where the tale ofLegacy of Kain: Soul Reaverleft off, Eidos Interactive's sequel begins as the ancient vampire Raziel emerges from the Chronoplast time portal. He has traveled back into Nosgoth's past to continue his relentless pursuit of Kain, his nemesis and father.Over the course of his journey, Raziel unearths the mysteries behind Nosgoth's ancient races, and exposes the secrets behind the corruption of the Pillars and the vampire genocide. As Raziel confronts the shadows of his unremembered past, he discovers a web of destiny stretching eons into Nosgoth's history. With his destiny about to come full circle, Raziel finds the fate of Nosgoth hanging in the balance and his personal vendetta transformed into a hero's journey.Soul Reaverfans will also be engaged by the sequel's expanded lock-and-key puzzle system and the increased number and variety of enemies and spells. The game also plays with greater fluidity due to its constant 60-frames-per-second run rate.
summary: Yes it's short but still great.
reviewText: I almost feel compelled to defend Soul Reaver 2.  When I wrote my first review for this game I had not beaten it yet.  But now that I have finished the game I feel I can offer a defense for the game.Yes it is a fairly short game.  But really why does that matter?  Would people rather have a game that's endless hours of boring game play (Dark Angel comes to mind) or a game that is not very long yet offers a compelling story line, fantastic gameplay and top-notch voice acting?  There are plenty of games that you could purchase that would be longer in playing time, but not hold a candle to Soul Reaver 2's quality.  And isn't that what we want as gamers, quality gaming?Sure I wish the game would have been longer too, but that shortcoming doesn't make me wish I never purchased the game.  The story line is so incredible that it ranks up there with some of the best games I have ever purchased.  Yes Soul Reaver 1 was a longer game, but how many people got tired of the Drowned Abbey section of the game, or the pointless finding of the glyphs (they really had no bearing on the game).  Soul Reaver 2 has less wondering around and gives you better direction on where to go and what to do.Another knock on the game that I have read is that it is too much watching and not enough playing.  I can understand this, but the story line is the driving force behind Soul Reaver 2.  It's answering questions that span 2 previous games and tying in all the story lines.  Which by the way they do fantastically.So in my opinion this game is not a waste of your (money).  Though it may be short, it is a lot of bang for your buck.

description: Wii Play collects nine quick and addictive games that are easy to pick up and play and hard to put away. Thanks to the intuitive controls of the Wii Remote, even the most inexperienced gamers will have no trouble mastering the controls.    <p> Wii Play features nine separate mini-games, including the following: <li>Shooting Range, a point-and-fire game of target practice in the Duck Hunt tradition. <li>Billiards, a simplified variation of nine-ball with stunningly realistic physics that uses your Wii Remote as your pool cue. <li>Find Mii, in which you scan the crowds to find the right Mii—and Miis you and your friends created make an appearance. <li>Tanks!, in which you command a toy tank on a miniature battlefield in a gauntlet of 100 missions. <li>Other games include Pose Mii, Table Tennis, Fishing, Charge!, and Laser Hockey. <p> Every game features a multiplayer mode, so you and your friends can compete for the high score or go head to head to see who’s the best.  Wii Play comes with a white Wii Remote so that your friends can join in the action. (Nunchuk not included.)
reviewText: This game is really a handful of mini games that serve as a primer on the use of the wii remote.  They lack the depth and replay factor of the sports title that comes with the wii.  They are more involved, however, than the mini games of wario ware. They are right in the middle.Many reviews seem to think this game is going to serve as a sequel to wii sports.  It's nothing like that game, and I think people who are expecting that level of complexity and fun are in for a rude awakening.  For example, don't think the table tenis game will be as good as the tenis sports title because it isn't and doesn't try to be.  It's a mini game.  The laser pong is fun, though, and the duck hunt game is a great blast from the past, as is combat.Of course the big issue is the extra remote.  You get the remote and game together for $50.  Is the wiiplay game worth $10?  Absolutely!  (I mean, it has far more playability than the Xbox 360 burger king games for a similar price point, plus without all the corporate propaganda!)For all the naysayers talking bad about this game, I think they miss the point of it.  This is a great $10 title.  If it were packaged at that price as a stand alone without the remote, I'd buy it (and any similar sequels they'd release).  At my house, we play the sports title as a party game on the weekends, and this game will serve the same purpose.  You and your friends will have fun with 2 person multi here (I know, no 4 player, but come on, ten bucks remember?), or even just passing the remote around and trying some more truly innovative wii gaming here--just wait until you play the cow race mini game with your friends gathere around!Bottom line is, remotes are harder to come by than Wii's during this initial wii release.  If you can get your hands on this, you're silly not to get your hands on the remote.  This is a game you should get right now.  Don't wait.  First, for that remote, and second, in a few months, the novelty of the wii remote will be getting stale, and there will be better games that make use this awesome technology.  If you get the game now, though, it'll be great fun while the system is still fresh.

reviewText: I really did not plan on buying Black Ops...I loved COD 2, but didn't like COD 4 at all.  After hearing numerous previews, and getting a good pre-order deal, I went for it.  This is not a perfect game, but it really is a lot of fun, and that's what I buy games for.I know most reviewers like to measure framerates, graphic comparisons, etc...I'm not big on that level of tech talk, but I can tell you the game looks and plays great.  I played through it once, and spent a lot of time online, and it has never frozen or even stuttered.  I didn't play the last two COD games, so I don't know how evolved it is from the last one, but as a game on it's own merit, it is a very good game.  There is a storyline that runs through all the missions...basically, the missions reflect some top secret missions occurring during the cold war era, in places such as Cuba and Vietnam.  Not revealing too much, the general plotline borrows a bit from the Assassin's Creed series; an unknown group is going through your memories from mission to mission, trying to get to certain information.  Some of the missions get a bit frustrating, but not deal-breakingly so.  There are a couple of levels where your next goal wasn't as obvious as it could have been, and this can be frustrating, but this doesn't make for a bad game, it just takes it from being a great game to being a very good game.  The controls are very smooth, and very easy to pick up.  There are a great deal of different weapons that you will use, which does a lot towards keeping the gameplay fresh.Though I haven't played the last couple of COD games, even I know that the multiplayer experience is really the focus of the COD franchise.  I'm not a fantastic FPS player, but I have spent a long time on that mode, and have really enjoyed it.  There are several different modes of play; you start with team mode, a mercenary team mode (players are randomly assigned teams) and a free-for-all mode.  Playing more and more of the game unlocks other modes, weapons, maps and contracts.  Contracts are basically goals within the game...beat a certain number of people using a certain weapon, for example...which you purchase using COD money earned by playing the game.  Meeting the goal wins you a certain amount of money from the contract; missing it obviously costs you whatever you spent on the contract.  There are wager matches, where you bet on the results of matches. There are special modes like One In The Chamber, where you start with a gun with a single bullet.  If you kill one of the other players, you get their bullets.  Otherwise, you must rely on melee weapons.  The progression of multiplayer really encourages you to play more and more, to unlock all the modes, weapons and other bonuses available.  This is really what brought me to get this game, the variety of gameplay available in multiplayer is huge, and will likely be about the only online FPS I will be playing for quite some time.  I am really not very good, but the matchmaking and gameplay variety have made it a real blast to play.  There is also a training mode for those of us who haven't done a lot of multiplayer games, or just want to familiarize themselves with the game before heading online.  I think this is a great addition to the game; hardcore players may never venture into it, but to others of us, it's a great training ground.Maybe my favorite mode is the Zombie mode.  Basically, you are locked away in a certain area, and must figure out how to accomplish some goals then get yourself out of there.  Zombies are coming at you with gradually increasing vigor, and you must deal with them.  Every time you kill one, you get a certain amount of points.  Points are not just a part of your score, they are used as currency.  It's up to you to decide if you want to spend your points on new weapons, upgraded ammo, or using them to open up a new area.  Do you hang out in a certain room, picking off zombies and running up your score?  If you do, you will hit the harder areas, with tougher, faster, deadlier zombies, so be careful how you spend them.  Make sure you finish the main single player mode at least once to open up a hilarious zombie level!This game has come with a ton of hype, and has already become one of the best-selling games of all time.  Don't let that sway you either way.  I have enjoyed this game a lot, there are tons of things to do, and s.  I would really recommend anyone with an interest in this game give it a try...but it, rent it, whatever.  I don't really have the basis of the last two games to guide my opinion either way, but on it's own merit, I think this is a very good game that is definitely worth playing.

summary: Pure fun, without all that "morality" getting in the way
reviewText: Infamous and Prototype were released at almost the same time, and, naturally, comparisons between the two started to fly. In the end, neither game came out on top, but the same cannot be said for their sequels, in my opinion. I purchased and played through Infamous 2 first, so know that I am qualified to say that Prototype 2 is far more fun.Before I go over the story, let me start by saying this is not a kids game. Nothing about this game is appropriate for children. Everything from the combat to the language to the subject matter is very much adult. Your character, Sgt James Heller, is a former marine who goes after Alex Mercer, star of the previous game, looking for revenge for the death of his family. Mercer defeats Heller, but instead of killing him, turns him into something like him. The story is your standard affair, but still manages to be engaging.The characters in Prototype 2 talk like real people, in that cursing is very much part of their vocabulary. If you are averse to strong language, stay far away from Prototype 2. Personally, I found it refreshing to hear characters talk like people really do. There are no heroes in this world. Heller is out for revenge, pure and simple. He may stop people from doing bad things, but that in no way means that he won't do bad things himself. This is an aspect that I find superior to Infamous 2.In Infamous 2, your character is a blank slate until you choose between "good" and "evil". In Prototype 2, morality isn't an issue. you want revenge and you are going to get it, any way you can, and that is where the fun kicks in. From the get go, Heller can jump twenty feet in the air, run up the side of a building, glide to another, and then action star karate kick an enemy soldier across the horizon. As you grow stronger, you can choose which abilities you want to grow with you. If you put the premium on getting around town, upgrade movement. If you're having trouble with the fights, give yourself more health and regeneration. You can upgrade your character to suit your personal play style, and it works wonderfully.You will get out of this game what you put into it. If you want to fly though the interesting, and engaging story missions, you are free to do so. If you dig a little deeper though, there are hours of game play to be found. From finding black boxes scattered across the city, to sabotaging your enemies movements, to a few interesting mini games, there is a plethora of things to do.The Combat is fun and fluid, but not as precise as I would like. This isn't really the games fault, but more a side effect of the fact that modern games feel the need to be "accessible". Gone are the days when not being able to beat a level meant that you had to try harder. Finishing moves are executed with a single button press, but as the game progresses and the screen fills with dozens of enemies, expect to grab some random zombie and impotently chuck them at the wall instead of finishing off the wounded enemy that has a precious ability upgrade. This isn't a big issue, but it is present.Overall, Prototype 2 is a grown up game with a lot to offer. Tons of fun, hours of game play and a new game plus feature adds replay value, and the story is compelling enough to keep you playing long past the time you promised yourself you would stop. Highly recommended and a definite buy.
